name: Diwali
shortDescription: Hindu Festival of Lights celebrating the victory of light over darkness, good over evil, and knowledge over ignorance through five days of ritual, celebration, and illumination
fullDescription: Diwali (Deepavali, meaning 'row of lights') is one of the most important and widely celebrated festivals in Hinduism, observed over five days during the lunar month of Kartika (October-November). The festival commemorates multiple mythological events‚Äîmost prominently, Lord Rama's return to Ayodhya after 14 years of exile and his victory over the demon king Ravana; the victory of Lord Krishna over the demon Narakasura; and Lakshmi Puja honoring the goddess of wealth and prosperity. The festival's central practice involves lighting countless oil lamps (diyas), candles, and decorative lights to symbolize the triumph of light over darkness, knowledge over ignorance, and good over evil. Each of the five days has specific rituals: Dhanteras (wealth worship), Naraka Chaturdashi (cleansing), Lakshmi Puja (main celebration), Govardhan Puja (Krishna worship), and Bhai Dooj (sibling bonds). Families thoroughly clean and decorate homes with rangoli designs, perform elaborate pujas, exchange gifts and sweets, wear new clothes, and participate in fireworks displays. Diwali marks the beginning of the new year in many Hindu traditions and represents spiritual renewal, the victory of dharma, and the hope that light will always overcome darkness.

requirements.timing: Five days during new moon (Amavasya) of Kartika month (October-November), dates vary by lunar calendar
requirements.practitioner: All Hindu families and individuals, led by head of household or priest for elaborate pujas
requirements.preparation: Weeks of cleaning, shopping, decorating, preparing sweets, purchasing new clothes and gifts

steps.description: Purchase gold, silver, or utensils; worship Dhanvantari (god of health) and Lakshmi; light first diyas
Early morning oil bath for purification; celebrate Krishna's victory over Narakasura; light lamps
Homes meticulously cleaned and decorated; elaborate Lakshmi Puja in evening; light maximum diyas; fireworks; feasting
Bathing Lakshmi's feet, offering flowers and sweets, chanting mantras, asking for prosperity and wisdom
Lighting rows of diyas throughout home, in doorways, windows, courtyards, and around property
Sharing elaborate vegetarian feast with traditional sweets and delicacies
Setting off fireworks to celebrate and ward off evil spirits
Worshipping Lord Krishna and Mount Govardhan; creating symbolic mountain from cow dung or food
Offering mountain of food to Krishna in temples
Sisters perform tikka ceremony for brothers; celebrating sibling bonds with gifts and meals
Throughout festival, exchanging gifts and sweets with family, friends, and business associates
Prayers for prosperity and success in the coming year (for those traditions where Diwali marks new year)

effects: Diwali brings spiritual renewal, purification from past sins and negative energies, and invites prosperity and good fortune through Lakshmi's blessing. The festival strengthens family and community bonds, marks new beginnings, and reaffirms the triumph of dharma (righteousness). Lighting diyas dispels darkness from homes and hearts, symbolizing the victory of knowledge over ignorance. Participants experience joy, hope, and renewed commitment to righteous living. The festival also brings practical benefits through home cleaning, financial planning (new account books), and social connection.
warnings: Diwali fireworks can cause injuries, fires, and air pollution‚Äîincreasingly controversial in modern times. Excessive gambling (traditionally permitted during Diwali) can lead to financial problems. The festival's commercialization raises concerns about materialism overshadowing spiritual meaning. Environmental concerns about firecracker waste and noise pollution have led to calls for 'green Diwali' celebrations.

mythologyContexts.usage: Diwali synthesizes multiple Hindu traditions and stories, demonstrating Hinduism's diversity. Different regions emphasize different mythological events‚ÄîNorth India focuses on Rama's return, South India on Krishna's victory over Narakasura, and West India on Vishnu's banishment of demon king Bali. The festival embodies core Hindu values: the victory of good over evil, importance of light/knowledge, honoring of prosperity, family bonds, and cyclical renewal.
mythologyContexts.mythicalOrigins: Multiple origin stories: (1) Rama returned to Ayodhya after defeating Ravana, welcomed by citizens lighting lamps; (2) Krishna defeated demon Narakasura, freeing 16,000 captive women; (3) Lakshmi emerged from the cosmic ocean during the churning of the Milky Sea; (4) Vishnu banished demon king Bali but granted him return for one day annually.

mythologyContexts.symbolism: The diya (lamp) represents the individual soul (atman) whose light dispels ignorance. The five days mirror the five elements and five stages of spiritual evolution. Lakshmi represents not just material wealth but spiritual prosperity and abundance. Fireworks symbolize driving away darkness and negative forces. Cleaning represents purification of body, mind, and spirit. New clothes symbolize renewal and fresh beginnings. The festival embodies Hindu belief that light/knowledge will ultimately triumph over darkness/ignorance.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Diwali is celebrated by over a billion people worldwide, making it one of the world's most widely observed festivals. It transcends Hindu communities, celebrated also by Jains (marking Mahavira's nirvana), Sikhs (release of Guru Hargobind), and some Buddhists. The festival has become a national holiday in India, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Myanmar, Mauritius, Guyana, Trinidad, Fiji, and Singapore. Diwali shapes Indian cultural identity, drives enormous economic activity, and has gained global recognition with celebrations from the White House to the British Parliament to the Sydney Opera House.

archetypes.analysis: Diwali commemorates cosmic battles‚ÄîRama's defeat of Ravana and Krishna's victory over Narakasura‚Äîrepresenting the eternal struggle between good and evil, order and chaos, with light/knowledge ultimately triumphing over darkness/ignorance.

The festival quintessentially embodies the universal archetype of light conquering darkness, both literally (through millions of lamps) and symbolically (knowledge over ignorance, good over evil, consciousness over unconsciousness).
Diwali marks new beginnings‚Äînew year for many traditions, new clothes, new account books, spiritual renewal through purification, and cyclical regeneration of hope and prosperity.
